text: Also, admin insists they are conducting real community outreach. Does this sound like the public has a chance to influence anything? "Neighborhood Advisory Committee meetings are purely advisory and don’t have a formal government role, nor do they vote on any aspect of the plan."
author: Jill_Jorgensen

text: Here's City Hall's most recent explanation for barring the press from meetings -- open to general public -- about jails. Any lawyers want to weigh in on the legality of excluding the media, comprised of members of the public, from a meeting open to the public?
author: Jill_Jorgensen

text: Sure, the Mueller report is finished, but have you guys heard about the draft environmental impact statement for four new city jails?
author: Jill_Jorgensen

text: Anyway, pretty wild to insist you are conducting serious outreach to communities and then moments later say some of that outreach needs to be kept secret from the press -- and as such, the people who live in these communities but aren't selected of the advisory panels.
author: Jill_Jorgensen

text: Under Carrion's logic, why not shut the press out of the entire ULURP process for the jails, so people can be super extra honest? Slippery slope here. I hope some news org's attorney delves into whether this exclusion is legal.
author: Jill_Jorgensen

text: Community Affairs Commissioner Marco Carrion says excluding the press from meetings about borough based jails allows people to speak more openly. But people speak freely all the time in front of reporters at public meetings.
author: Jill_Jorgensen

text: When will the mayor visit one? WHEN WILL THE MAYOR PET A DOG, SAM?!
author: Jill_Jorgensen

text: "Keyword false. She is not in the discussions on the choice of the new chair, that is being done with the leadership of HUD in Washington and with the Southern District, extraordinarily productive conversations basically on a daily basis," @NYCMayor continued.

text: .@JSandersNYC, also here, seems to be undecided -- he made a joke of cutting off his mic when asked if he was a yes or no for congestion pricing.
author: Jill_Jorgensen

text: .@NYCMayor spent his subway ride up here trying to get people to support congestion pricing. He might want to talk to @AMBichotte, who is here at his presser and says she is against congestion pricing as it currently stands.

text: Can’t imagine these packed mayoral rides improve the commute if anyone on the subway.
